New Records: Florian Wirtz scored the fastest international goal in history, just 7 seconds into the match
Key Match Events: Florian Wirtz scored the opening goal with a fierce dipping drive at just 7 seconds into the match
Kai Havertz slotted the visitors into a two-goal lead with a goal just after half-time

Jamal Musiala was left with far too much space in the box when Wirtz found him with a long pass and the Bayern Munich youngster rounded Samba before laying the ball on a plate for the on-rushing Havertz
Mittelstädt mistimed a clearance on to his own arm, but VAR then adjudged the handball inside the box to be unintentional
Pre-Game Insights: Both teams are preparing for the European Championship this summer
France coach Didier Deschamps rang the changes on the hour mark but without Antoine Griezmann, missing his first international since 2017
Post-Match Reflections: France lacked a cutting edge despite the presence of star striker Kylian Mbappé
New coach Julian Nagelsmann's charges looked the more likely to score the next goal
Miscellaneous Highlights: Both sides continue their preparations for this summer's European Championship, with France taking on Chile and Germany hosting old rivals Netherlands on Tuesday
Others: Toni Kroos, playing his first international since 2021, received the ball from kick-off and chipped it forward to Leverkusen playmaker Wirtz
Christoph Baumgartner's earlier strike inside seven seconds would have equalled the record for the fastest recorded international goal – scored in 2013 by compatriot Lukas Podolski
